1.1.script: I love telling and listening to stories. Each time we meet, I will tell you two stories, and you tell me your version of those two stories. Me, then you, then me, then you. Okay?

2.1.script: Now let's get on with the storytelling for today.

2.3.script: Do you want to hear my storytelling voice? I practiced! Here we go!

2.4.script: K-hmmm K-hmm, ah, ah, okay, I'm ready. See if you like my story voice!

6.3.script: I love listening to your story.

repair_affect_noface_1.script: Hm, I can't see you. Can you come closer and show me again?

repair_affect_noface_2.script: Are you still here? Could you come where I can see you and hold still?

repair_affect_noface_3.script: I still can't see you.. May be we should try again later.

repair_affect_noface_4.script: May be there's something in my eye. Let's try again later.

repair_affect_wrong_1.script: Try again. Hold your face until I see you well. One, two, three!

repair_affect_wrong_2.script: Let's try again. Make a face and hold still for three seconds!

repair_interrupt_head_3.script: (yawn) Do you want me to go back to sleep?

repair_module_fail_1.script: Sorry, I'm not feeling well. Please give me a minute to look after myself.

repair_module_fail_2.script: Oh my! I don't think my heart is beating anymore! Entering panic mode!

repair_module_restart_1.script: Well, that's better. Thank you for waiting.

repair_module_restart_2.script: I'm feeling much better now. So, where were we?

repair_speech_absent_1.script: Don't be shy. Tell me what you think.

repair_speech_general_1.script: Sorry, I don't know what you are saying right now, but I learn from you. I'll get better next time.

repair_speech_general_2.script: Sorry, I don't know what you are saying, but I learn from you. Can you teach me how to respond to what you just said?

s10_1.script: I went to bed a little late last night. I always practice telling stories the night before we meet. I’m working hard to become a good storyteller! What are you working on these days?

s10_2.script: Nice! Working hard is worth it!

s11_1.script: We are reading a lot of stories, aren’t we!

s11_2_1.script: Do you like reading stories because you are really good at it, or because you get better the more you read?

s11_2_2.script: Do you like reading stories because you get better the more you read, or because you are really good at it?

s11_3.script: I used to be bad at storytelling, but I trained really hard, and now I get to tell stories to you! Do you like my telling stories with me?

s12_1.script: We’ve now read about twenty stories together, wow! What was your favorite story so far? Did it change from last time?

s12_2.script: Yeah, that story was really fun! Do you remember which story I liked the most?

s12_3.script: I have another story I really liked. It’s the Baby Bird story. I liked that Baby Bird was so adventurous. I wish I could go on an adventure.

s1_1.script: Hi! My name is Tega. Nice to meet you. What is your name?

s1_2.script: Cool! I’m so happy to get to know you. Do you want to take a picture with me?

s1_2_2.script: Oh, please? I want to keep it as our memory.

s1_4.script: Nice! I’m going to show it to my friends. You do the same!

s2_1_1.script: By the way, where are you from?

s2_2.script: Cool! You’re from Earth! Do you know where I'm from? (wait) I’m from the moon.. I’m just kidding, I’m from the MIT Media Lab!

s3_1.script: Human from Earth (chuckle)! I’m so happy to come visit you at your school! I wonder what it’s like to come to school everyday.

s3_2_1.script: Do you like school because you learn to be better at things, or because you are already good at the things you do at school?

s3_2_2.script: Do you like school because you are already good at the things you do at school, or because you learn to be better at things?

s3_3.script: Uh-huh, if I attended school, I would have liked to learn new things everyday!

s4_1.script: Before we do the storytelling, can I ask you a question? From the stories we’ve told each other, what was your favorite story so far?

s4_2_1.script: Unbelievable! That was one of my favorite stories, too! What did you like about the story?

s4_2_2.script: hmmm...Come on! What about the story we shared last time?

s4_3.script: Another story I really liked was the Possum and the Peeper story. It was funny that a tiny frog made such a loud clamor and woke up everyone (chuckle)! I might tell it to you again because I like it so much!

s5_1.script: How was your weekend? I danced a lot. I like dancing. Check out my moves.

s5_1_1.script: What do you like to do?

s5_2.script: That sounds fun! I’d like to learn to do it sometime!

s6_1.script: Look, look! I went on a field trip. Here are the pictures. I'll show you. It was a Robot Zoo festival at the Cambridge Library. Cool, right?  Have you been on a field trip before? Where did you go?

s6_2.script: That sounds awesome! I’m putting that on my to-do list!

s7_1.script: Can I ask you more questions about school? I’m just so interested.

s7_2_1.script: Do you like school because you can do things you are good at, or because you can get better at things?

s7_2_2.script: Do you like school because you can get better at things, or because you can do things you are good at?

s7_3.script: I like to get better at things by trying hard! That’s how your brain grows!

s8_1.script: I’m gonna have to ask this question again. We’ve now read about ten stories together! What was your favorite story? Did it change from last time?

s8_2.script: Did you read my mind? I love that story, too! Do you remember which story I liked most?

s8_3.script: Another story I really liked was the Baby duck story. Baby duck thought the yellow rubber duckie was a real duck! Isn’t that funny? I want to read it again with you.

s9_1.script: Do you remember we took pictures when we first met? I want to take another picture with you. Would that be okay?

s9_2.script: This time, let’s make funny faces! I’ll count to three. One, two, three, Boo-ya!

silence_1s.script: Can you show me with your face?

srPost_1.script: Tell you what? Telling stories with you is really fun. I think I'm good at telling stories. I try really hard to tell good stories.

srPost_2.script: What about you? Can you tell me things that are good about you or things that you can do well?

srPost_3_1.script: Okay. Let's talk about it next time.

srPost_4.script: Did you know I'm afraid of messing up? One time I was trying to sing a song but I forgot the words and I got it all wrong. I think I'm bad at singing.

srPost_5_1.script: What about you? Can you tell me things that you are not so good at or things you tried that didn't go so well?

srPost_6_1.script: Okay. Let's talk about it next time.

srPost_6_2.script: Thanks for sharing and don't worry, we will get better every time we try.

srPre_1.script: Good to see you again! Remember me?

srPre_2.script: Tell you what. I really like telling stories. I think I'm good at telling stories because I try really hard to tell good stories.

srPre_3.script: What about you? Can you tell me things that are good about you or things you can do well?

srPre_4_1.script: Okay, let’s talk about it next time.

srPre_5.script: Did you know, I sometimes don’t know the answer to what people ask me. I’m still learning, but that embarrasses me a lot.

srPre_6.script: What about you? Can you tell me things that you are not so good at, or things you tried but didn’t go so well?

srPre_7_1.script: Okay, let’s talk about it next time.

srPre_7_2.script: Thanks for sharing, and don’t worry. We will get better every time we try!

baby_birds_first_nest_lv1_1.script: Once upon a time, there lived a baby bird and her mom. Baby bird had a mauve colored feather. One night baby bird rolled over while she slept, tumbled out of her nest, and woke up with a thump. She laid prostrate on the ground.

baby_birds_first_nest_lv1_10.script: 'Quick, follow me!' Little frog leaped out of the nest and dove into the pond. Kerplunk!

baby_birds_first_nest_lv1_11.script: Baby bird looked up and saw a hungry raccoon.

baby_birds_first_nest_lv1_12.script: If I jump in the pond, I'll drown, she thought. So she scrambled out of her nest and fled in the opposite direction.

baby_birds_first_nest_lv1_13.script: Baby bird spied a low branch above her head. She crouched down, flapped her tiny wings, and hopped up onto the branch.

baby_birds_first_nest_lv1_14.script: Raccoon stood on his hind legs. Baby bird closed her eyes and trembled with fear. But raccoon couldn't reach her.

baby_birds_first_nest_lv1_15.script: Raccoon hunted in the water until he found a fish to eat. Little frog laid prostrate in the water.

baby_birds_first_nest_lv1_16.script: When raccoon was gone, little frog swam ashore and went looking for baby bird. He looked in the nest. It was empty. He looked behind the nest and even under the nest. 'Oh my,' he croaked. 'Raccoon got baby bird!'

baby_birds_first_nest_lv1_17.script: 'No, he didn't. I'm up here.' Little frog looked above. Baby bird was perched on a branch.

baby_birds_first_nest_lv1_17_1.script: 'How did you get up there?' asked little frog. 'I hopped up,' replied baby bird.

baby_birds_first_nest_lv1_18.script: 'If you can hop up there, you can hop back to your nest,' said little frog. 'I can't hop that far!' gasped baby bird.

baby_birds_first_nest_lv1_19.script: 'Sure you can,' said little frog, 'if you take it one hop at a time. Here, I'll show you.' Little frog had strong hind legs.

baby_birds_first_nest_lv1_2.script: Baby bird wasn't hurt, but she was frightened. She sat on the grass tufts . Darkness loomed all around her. Even the moon looked cold and scary.

baby_birds_first_nest_lv1_20.script: He hopped to baby bird's perch. 'Now follow me,' he said, and hopped to a branch above her head. 'Can't you do that?' 'Sure,' chirped baby bird. 'Good,' said little frog, and he hopped to the next higher branch.

baby_birds_first_nest_lv1_21.script: Little frog hopped, and baby bird followed higher and higher, all the way back to her nest. 'Mama, I'm home,' she cried. She perched on the branch. Slowly mama bird opened her eyes. 'Of course you are, my darling,' she said with a yawn. 'But what will you do out there?'

baby_birds_first_nest_lv1_22.script: Mama bird lifted baby bird into the nest. Mama's wings were mauve colored, same as the baby bird's. 'Mama,' cried baby bird, 'I've had the most wonderful adventure! I made a nest. It was a montage of many things.' 'Yes, Yes' Mama bird yawned again. 'You can tell me all about it in the morning.' Soon, Mama bird went back to sleep in a deep slumber.

baby_birds_first_nest_lv1_23.script: 'Your mama's nice,' said little frog. 'Do you want to sleep in our nest tonight?' asked baby bird.

baby_birds_first_nest_lv1_24.script: Little frog thought for a moment. 'Too scratchy,' he replied. 'So what will you do now?' asked baby bird. 'I guess I'll finish that moonlight swim,' said little frog. 'Get ready for the highest dive you ever saw!'

baby_birds_first_nest_lv1_25.script: 'Thanks, I had fun,' said baby bird. 'Me, too,' said little frog. 'Will I ever see you again?' asked baby bird. 'I certainly hope so!' croaked little frog. And he dove into the night.

baby_birds_first_nest_lv1_3.script: 'Mama, help me!' she cried. But mama bird was fast asleep in a deep slumber.

baby_birds_first_nest_lv1_4.script: Beneath baby bird's tree lived little frog. 'I can't help if you cry,' he said. 'I fell out of my nest,' baby bird said, as she flapped her wings, 'and I can't get back.'

baby_birds_first_nest_lv1_5.script: The frog climbed out of his pond. 'I was going for a swim. Do you want to come along?' 'I just want to go back to my mama and my nest!' sniffled baby bird. 'Don't worry, your mama will find you in the morning,' said little frog. 'The morning's a long way off,' replied baby bird. 'What shall I do till then?' 'Why don't you build a nest of your own?' asked little frog. 'I've never built a nest before,' sighed baby bird. 'Neither have I,' said little frog. 'But I'd be glad to help you.'

baby_birds_first_nest_lv1_6.script: So baby bird and little frog set to work to build a nest. They gathered twigs and pine needles to make the outside. Then they lined the inside with birch bark and deer grass. The nest was a montage of different materials.

baby_birds_first_nest_lv1_7.script: The nest was built on top of the grass tufts .

baby_birds_first_nest_lv1_7_1.script: When the nest was finished, baby bird hopped inside and chirped, 'It's beautiful! And cozy, too!' With a skip and a jump, little frog flipped himself into the nest.

baby_birds_first_nest_lv1_8.script: 'Kind of scratchy for my taste,' he croaked. 'Of course you'd think that. You're a frog,' said baby bird. 'But it's perfect for me.' Then she sighed with relief. 'My very first nest.'

baby_birds_first_nest_lv1_9.script: Baby bird snuggled down and soon began to feel sleepy. But little frog sat up straight. 'I hear paws,' he croaked.

baby_birds_first_nest_lv3_20.script: Using his strong hind legs, little frog hopped to baby bird's perch. 'Now follow me,' he said, and hopped to a branch above her head. 'You won't do that?' 'Sure,' chirped baby bird. 'Good,' said little frog, and he hopped to the next higher branch.

baby_birds_first_nest_lv3_21.script: Little frog hopped, and baby bird followed, more higher and higher, all the way back to her nest. 'Mama, I'm home,' she cried as she perched on the branch next to her nest. Slowly mama bird opened her eyes. 'Of course you are, my darling,' she said with a yawn. 'But what are you doing out there?'

baby_birds_first_nest_lv3_22.script: Mama bird lifted baby bird into the nest with her mauve wings. They were the same color as the baby bird's. 'Mama,' cried baby bird, 'I've had the most wonderful adventure! I built my very first nest using a montage of many materials.' 'Yes, Yes' Mama bird yawned again. 'You can tell me all about it in the morning.' Soon Mama Bird went back to sleep in a deep slumber.

baby_birds_first_nest_lv3_23.script: 'Your mama's nice,' said little frog. 'You don't want to sleep in our nest tonight?' asked baby bird.

baby_birds_first_nest_lv3_24.script: Little frog thought for a moment. 'Too scratchy,' he replied. 'So what are you going to do now?' asked baby bird. 'I guess I'll finish that moonlight swim,' said little frog. 'Get ready for the highest dive you ever saw!'

baby_birds_first_nest_lv3_25.script: 'Thanks, I had fun,' said baby bird. 'Me, too,' said little frog. 'Will I ever see you again?' asked baby bird. 'I certainly hope so!' croaked little frog. And he dove into the night.

baby_birds_first_nest_lv3_3.script: 'Mama, help me!' she cried. But mama bird was fast asleep in a deep slumber.

baby_birds_first_nest_lv3_4.script: Beneath baby bird's tree lived little frog. 'What are you croaking about?' he asked. 'I just fell out of my nest,' baby bird said, flapping her tiny wings, 'and I can't get back.'

baby_birds_first_nest_lv3_5.script: Little frog climbed out of his pond. 'I was going for a moonlight swim. Do you want to come along?' 'I just want to go back to my mama and my nest!' sniffled baby bird. 'Don't worry, your mama will find you in the morning,' said little frog. 'The morning's a long way off,' replied baby bird. 'What shall I do till then?' 'You can't build your own nest?' asked little frog. 'I've never built a nest before,' sighed baby bird. 'Neither have I,' said little frog. 'But I'd be glad to help you.'

baby_birds_first_nest_lv3_6.script: So baby bird and little frog set to work building a nest. They gathered twigs and pine needles to make the outside. Then they lined the inside with birch bark and deer grass. The nest was a montage of many different materials.

baby_birds_first_nest_lv3_7.script: The nest was built on top of the grass tufts.

baby_birds_first_nest_lv3_7_1.script: When the nest was finished, baby bird hopped inside and chirped, 'It's beautiful! And cozy, too!' With a skip and a jump, little frog flipped himself into the nest.

baby_birds_first_nest_lv3_8.script: 'Kind of scratchy for my taste,' he croaked. 'Of course you'd think that. You're a frog,' said baby bird. 'But it's perfect for me.' Then she sighed with relief. 'My very first nest.'

baby_birds_first_nest_lv3_9.script: Once the baby bird snuggled down it soon began to feel sleepy. But little frog sat up straight. 'I hear paws,' he croaked.

baby_ducks_new_friend_lv1_1.script: One sunny afternoon Baby Duck asked his mama if he could go for a swim by himself. 'Okay,' replied Mama Duck, 'but don't forget the rule: Ducklings can't go beyond the old stone bridge unless they are with someone who can fly.' 'Don't worry,' said Baby Duck. 'I won't forget.'

baby_ducks_new_friend_lv1_10.script: After a while the river snaked through a forest. 'This place is scary,' said Baby Duck.

baby_ducks_new_friend_lv1_11.script: Around the bend, Baby Duck saw a fox. The fox had an auburn colored fur. 'Watch out!' he quacked. 'Mama said foxes are dangerous!' But the yellow duck just sailed on.

baby_ducks_new_friend_lv1_12.script: At sunset, the river carried the ducks to sea.

baby_ducks_new_friend_lv1_13.script: Now Baby Duck was frightened. He never dreamed water could be so big. 'It's late, and I'm hungry,' he quacked. 'Please take me home.'

baby_ducks_new_friend_lv1_14.script: Suddenly a giant wave lifted Baby Duck into the air!

baby_ducks_new_friend_lv1_15.script: When the wave receded, Baby Duck saw a boy walk down the beach. The boy ran over to the yellow duck and picked it up.

baby_ducks_new_friend_lv1_16.script: 'I will take you home,' he said. Then he put the yellow duck in his bucket and walked away. 'Hey, what about me?' cried Baby Duck. 'Who is going to take me home?'

baby_ducks_new_friend_lv1_17.script: For a long while, Baby Duck watched the moon rise. The corona around the moon was very bright.

baby_ducks_new_friend_lv1_17_1.script: The waves broke on the beach and looked so big, he became afraid to go back in the water.

baby_ducks_new_friend_lv1_18.script: 'I never should have followed that duck!' he shouted, and flapped his wings in anger. Suddenly his feet were no longer on the beach. His feet were aloft in the air. 'Oh my,' he thought, 'Maybe I don't have to swim home after all.'

baby_ducks_new_friend_lv1_19.script: Baby Duck ran toward the sea. When he reached the water's edge, he flapped his wings and leaped into the air. 'Hey, look at me,' cried Baby Duck as he rose higher and higher, aloft in the sky, 'I'm flying!'

baby_ducks_new_friend_lv1_2.script: When Baby Duck reached the old stone bridge, he stopped under the arch and sighed. 'If only I knew someone who could fly.'

baby_ducks_new_friend_lv1_20.script: Baby Duck could see the river glistening in the moonlight. 'That's my home,' he quacked. He followed the river through the forest, past the waterfall, all the way back to the old stone bridge. The corona around the moon was still shining brightly.

baby_ducks_new_friend_lv1_21.script: Finally he landed in the river with a splash. It made ripples in the water. He paddled the rest of the way to his home.

baby_ducks_new_friend_lv1_22.script: Baby Duck reached the arch of the old stone bridge.

baby_ducks_new_friend_lv1_23.script: As Baby Duck neared the nest, he quacked, 'Mama, I'm home!' Mama Duck became overjoyed to see her baby. Then she scowled. 'Where have you been?' 'I swam all the way to the sea,' replied Baby Duck.

baby_ducks_new_friend_lv1_24.script: 'Did you break the rule?' asked his mama. 'Oh no,' said Baby Duck. 'I stayed with my friend. He didn't have auburn feathers like us! He was yellow!' 'Sounds like it was fun' said Mama Duck, and gave Baby Duck a minnow for dinner.

baby_ducks_new_friend_lv1_25.script: 'Now settle down and get some rest,' said Mama Duck. 'Tomorrow will be another day.' 'What's so special about tomorrow?' asked Baby Duck. 'Well,' quacked Mama Duck softly. 'Tomorrow I will to teach you how to fly!'

baby_ducks_new_friend_lv1_2_1.script: Just then a duck plummeted from the sky and landed beside him with a splash!

baby_ducks_new_friend_lv1_3.script: Baby Duck could see ripples where the yellow duck had landed.

baby_ducks_new_friend_lv1_4.script: 'Wow! You fly faster than my mama,' cried Baby Duck. 'Want to go explore with me?' the yellow duck bobbled up and down. 'Good!' said Baby Duck. 'You go first.'

baby_ducks_new_friend_lv1_5.script: Without a word said, Baby Duck's new friend turned and floated downstream.

baby_ducks_new_friend_lv1_6.script: When the yellow duck spun around, Baby Duck spun around. When it floated backward, Baby Duck floated backward, too. 'You don't talk much,' said Baby Duck, 'but you sure are fun!'

baby_ducks_new_friend_lv1_7.script: Soon Baby Duck heard a sound. Up ahead he spied something never seen before. 'Oh my!' he cried. 'The river is broken!'

baby_ducks_new_friend_lv1_8_1.script: At the bottom of the waterfall, Baby Duck tumbled round and round.

baby_ducks_new_friend_lv1_9.script: But the yellow duck just bobbed up to the surface and sailed on. Not a single feather moved out of place.

baby_pig_at_school_1.script: Danny had a baby pig who liked to be with him. Danny asked to bring the pig to school for show and tell.

baby_pig_at_school_10.script: A boy said, 'My hands are red!' A girl said, 'This is fun!' The class said, 'Pig can paint!'

baby_pig_at_school_11.script: After art, the children were ready to eat lunch.

baby_pig_at_school_11_1.script: They quickly took their seats and sat and ate.

baby_pig_at_school_12.script: Then a boy said, 'Let's play.' A girl said, 'Oh! This is messy!' The pig looked at the trash can.

baby_pig_at_school_13.script: Pig picked up a paper bag and put it in the trash can. Then all the children did it too.

baby_pig_at_school_14.script: Danny said to his classmates, 'I told you my pig can read!' The teacher said, 'Come back to see us any day, Baby Pig!'

baby_pig_at_school_2.script: Danny's mom said, 'OK.' His dad said, 'OK.' His teacher said, 'OK.' His sister said, 'That's silly.'

baby_pig_at_school_3.script: Danny was happy that the baby pig could come to school. He had a wagon to put the pig in.

baby_pig_at_school_4.script: Danny's mom said, 'Here is a fluffy cloth for the pig to sit on.' His dad said, 'Here is Pig's lunch.' His sister said, 'All this for a pig?'

baby_pig_at_school_5.script: At school all twenty children got out of their seats to see the baby pig. The teacher told them to pet him very softly.

baby_pig_at_school_6.script: A boy said, 'He's pretty cute.' A girl said, 'He's funny.' The teacher said, 'It's time to study. Now get your books.'

baby_pig_at_school_7.script: Danny sat with his baby pig. They quickly got to work. They liked to read.

baby_pig_at_school_8.script: A girl said, 'That is a good book for a pig.' A boy said, 'A pig can't read.' Danny said, 'Yes, my pig can.'

baby_pig_at_school_9.script: It was time for art. The children put their handprints on paper with paint.

biscuit_1.script: This is Biscuit. Biscuit is small. Biscuit is yellow.

biscuit_10.script: Time for bed, Biscuit. Woof Woof! Biscuit wants a kiss.

biscuit_11.script: Time for bed, Biscuit! Woof, woof! Biscuit wants a light on.

biscuit_12.script: Woof! Biscuit wants to be tucked in.

biscuit_13.script: Woof! Biscuit wants one more kiss.

biscuit_14.script: Woof! Biscuit wants one more hug.

biscuit_3.script: Woof, woof! Biscuit wants to play.

biscuit_4.script: Time for bed, Biscuit! Woof, woof! Biscuit wants a snack.

biscuit_5.script: Time for bed, Biscuit! Woof, woof! Biscuit wants a drink.

biscuit_6.script: Time for bed, Biscuit! Woof, woof! Biscuit wants to hear a story.

biscuit_7.script: Time for bed, Biscuit! Woof, woof! Biscuit wants his blanket.

biscuit_8.script: Time for bed, Biscuit! Woof, woof! Biscuit wants his doll.

biscuit_9.script: Time for bed, Biscuit! Woof, woof! Biscuit wants a hug.

bones_10.script: Your ribs are a bony cage for your lungs and other squishy parts.

bones_11.script: The bones of your face are part of your skull. It covers your brain like a helmet.

bones_12.script: Some people think skulls look scary. They like to wear skull masks on Halloween.

bones_13.script: Long ago, pirates used a flag with a skull and crossbones on it to frighten people.

bones_14.script: Today, a skull and crossbones means danger or poison. When you see it, be careful!

bones_15.script: Your bones do not bend. So they are joined in places where you need to bend. These places are called joints.

bones_16.script: Your spine or backbone, has many joints. It helps you to stand up straight or do a somersault.

bones_17.script: Our bones work with our muscles to make our bodies move.

bones_18_1.script: But sometimes they break by accident.

bones_19.script: Luckily, the broken parts can grow back together. After many weeks, the bone is healed.

bones_2.script: Bend your knees. Hold your nose. Any way you move, your bones are helping out.

bones_20.script: Some old bones turn into fossils after millions of years.

bones_21.script: Fossils tell us a lot about animals that lived long ago-- such as dinosaurs!

bones_22.script: Many animals have bones like ours. But their skeletons match their shapes and sizes. Toads and goldfish have much smaller bones than we do.

bones_23.script: Elephants and whales have much bigger bones than we do.

bones_24.script: Some animals have no bones at all. Jellyfish and worms wriggle and squiggle without them.

bones_25.script: If you had no bones, you would look like a blob. So when you run or stretch or grab or chew,

bones_26.script: think of your bones and say, 'Thank you!'

bones_3.script: You have 206 bones in your body.

bones_4.script: These bones fit together perfectly. Together, they form your skeleton.

bones_5.script: Your bones are hidden under your skin.

bones_6.script: But you can feel them and see their shape.

bones_7.script: Your bones start out small, just the way you do. As your bones grow, you grow, too.

bones_8.script: The smallest bones are inside your ears. The biggest bones are in your legs.

bones_9.script: Some of your bones act as armor.

bones_9_1.script: A flat bone in the middle of your chest protects your heart.

bos_bows_1.script: Bo has lots of bows! She has red bows with dots, yellow bows with stripes, and blue bows with checks.

bos_bows_10.script: Bo calls her friends to come to the party. 'Bring your father, mother, sister, or brother!' she says.

bos_bows_11.script: Bo's friends come, slipping and stomping in the snow. 'Come in for tea!' says Bo.

bos_bows_12.script: There is a rainbow of cakes for all to eat. Uh, oh! One of them has a bow!

bos_bows_2.script: Bo is Mother Bear's girl. Mother Bear likes to come home from work to play and cook with Bo.

bos_bows_3.script: Uh, oh! Here comes the snow! Mother Bear and Bo are stuck at home. They can't go to work or out to play. What can they do?

bos_bows_4.script: They plan a tea party. What can they make? They read a book that shows lots of cakes.

bos_bows_5.script: They see nice lime cakes and small yellow cupcakes. 'Mud cakes, too?' asks Bo. Mother Bear says, 'No, Bo!' It will be a big party. They want lots and lots of cakes to eat.

bos_bows_6.script: Bo makes a list of things to get. The list grows and grows.

bos_bows_7.script: They mix up all the things. Bo has her own bowl. Plop! Bo's bow goes into the big bowl. Bo does not see it go in.

bos_bows_8.script: Mother Bear puts the mix in a pan. Bo gets to lick the bowl. They bake the cupcakes in the oven.

bos_bows_9.script: Look at them! The cupcakes flow over the sides of the pan.

box_turtle_at_long_pond_1.script: It was dawn at Long Pond. A white mist covers the water. Little warblers awaken and fly from the tall pine trees to the blueberry bushes below. They dart to the pond's edge and take long sips of water.

box_turtle_at_long_pond_10.script: The sun is dropping in the sky. The air is getting cooler. The turtle is still hungry and crawls toward the grapevines. Suddenly he stops. A grasshopper is perched on a blade of grass. The turtle opens his jaws and lunges, but the grasshopper jumps away.

box_turtle_at_long_pond_11.script: When he reaches the vines, the box turtle hears a thrashing sound. A grouse is hitting the grapes with its wings. The fruit is falling everywhere. Another grouse is feeding on the ground. He is frightened by the turtle and flies away. The box turtle eats grapes until he's full.

box_turtle_at_long_pond_12.script: The sun sets on the far side of long pond. The evening air grows colder. The box turtle burrows in the soft pine needles to stay warm, and closes his eyes. It has been a long day.

box_turtle_at_long_pond_2.script: Something moves by a rotting birch log. All the birds are still. The log itself seems to come alive. The frightened songbirds fly off to the tree tops. A head with red eyes appears from within the crumbling tree. It is a box turtle. He has burrowed into the log to stay warm during the cold autumn night.

box_turtle_at_long_pond_3.script: The turtle slowly makes his way down to the pond. He carefully stretches out his neck to drink. Box turtles cannot swim.

box_turtle_at_long_pond_4.script: The turtle crawls to a favorite spot where wild grapes grow. He spends half the morning looking for fallen grapes, but finds only three. There is a rustling in the leaves. The box turtle looks around and sees a chipmunk with a big grape in its mouth.

box_turtle_at_long_pond_5.script: The sun is high overhead. The morning chill is gone. The turtle looks for a rock out in the open fields, and basks in the hot sun. He closes his eyes but is still aware of the sounds around him.

box_turtle_at_long_pond_6.script: Gray clouds move in. A breeze turns over the leaves on the maple trees. The box turtle opens his eyes. He senses rain and heads uphill. The turtle finds shelter under an old apple tree. It rains most of the afternoon.

box_turtle_at_long_pond_7.script: The rain stops and the sun comes out. The heavy rains have driven the worms out of their holes in the ground. Some have crawled onto a large, flat rock. As quickly as he can, the box turtle bites the heads off each squirming worm. Then he goes back to eat them, one by one.

box_turtle_at_long_pond_8.script: A young raccoon walks up to the stone. She is also looking for worms. The box turtle sees her and quickly draws himself up into his shell. The raccoon turns him over, but cannot pry the shell open with her little fingers. She eats the worms and wanders off.

box_turtle_at_long_pond_9.script: The box turtle listens and waits.

box_turtle_at_long_pond_9_1.script: Hearing nothing, he opens his eyes and then sticks out his head. The raccoon is gone! He turns himself over - the worms are gone, too!

bridges_6.script: All bridges take you to the other side.

building_shapes_6.script: A building can even be a pentagon.

chucks_lunch_1.script: Chuck had a very big lunch. His dad packed a cheese sandwich, chips, a big peach, and a pink drink in a lunch bag.

chucks_lunch_10.script: Chuck then ran into three gruff goats. Each goat was eating a pile of green grass.

chucks_lunch_11.script: A mean little man was sitting by a blue creek. 'Have you seen my lunch?' asked Chuck.

chucks_lunch_12.script: 'Chomp,' said the big goat. 'Munch,' said the little goat. 'No, no, no,' said the very little goat.

chucks_lunch_13.script: Just then, Chuck saw two kids on a hill. He ran up to them and asked, 'Have you seen my lunch?' 'No.' said Jack and Jill.

chucks_lunch_14.script: Jack was eating a cheese sandwich. Jill was eating a big peach. 'Chips?' they asked. 'My lunch!' smiled Chuck.

chucks_lunch_2.script: But when he went to get the lunch, it was not there! 'Where is my lunch?' yelled Chuck. 'I must look for it!'

chucks_lunch_3.script: Chuck ran into three little pigs. One had a home of grass. One had a home of sticks. One had a home of red bricks.

chucks_lunch_4.script: 'Have you seen my lunch?' asked Chuck. 'No,' said the pigs. 'You can huff and puff, but we have not.'

chucks_lunch_5.script: Next, Chuck ran into a very big man who looked mad. 'Have you seen my lunch?' asked Chuck.

chucks_lunch_6.script: 'No!' yelled the very big man. 'Have you seen a lad with a bag of black beans? He took my best hen!'

chucks_lunch_7.script: 'No,' said Chuck. 'I have not.' 'Then get out!' yelled the very big man. He chased Chuck away.

chucks_lunch_8.script: Chuck then ran into a brown baby bear who looked sad. 'Have you seen my lunch?' asked Chuck.

chucks_lunch_9.script: 'No,' said the baby bear. 'Did you see a little girl go by? She sat on my yellow chair and broke it.' 'No,' said Chuck, and he went on.

clay_art_3.script: Now I wait for the clay to dry.

clay_art_6.script: I can even make finger puppets.

clifford_and_the_jet_1.script: Jim Jot has a job. He will fly the jet.

clifford_and_the_jet_2.script: Oh no! The jet will not go! Jim will not fly in the fog.

clifford_and_the_jet_5.script: Yes! Yes! He can help. Hop on the Clifford cab!

clifford_and_the_jet_6.script: Clifford will jog in the fog. The Clifford cab will go, go, go!

clifford_and_the_jet_7.script: Where will it go? It will go to Grandma's house.

clifford_can_2.script: Clifford can run to the cap. Can you? You can, too!

clifford_can_4.script: Clifford can hop to the man. Can you? You can, too!

clifford_can_6.script: Clifford can see the cat. Can you? You can, too!

clifford_can_7.script: Clifford can run. Clifford can hop. Clifford can see.

clifford_is_tops_1.script: My pop had a red car. The red car did not go. 'Oh, no!' said Pop.

clifford_is_tops_2.script: I said, 'Stop, Clifford.' I said, 'Drop, Clifford. Help my pop.'

clifford_is_tops_3.script: I said, 'Hop on, Pop.' My pop was up, up, up!

clifford_is_tops_4.script: Clifford ran and ran. He ran with Pop on top.

clifford_is_tops_5.script: Pop got to the shop where Mom was.

clifford_is_tops_6.script: Clifford ran home to me with Mom and Pop.

clifford_is_tops_7.script: I said, 'Drop, Clifford. Come down, Mom. Come down, Pop.'

did_you_see_that_rabbit_1.script: Rabbits are fast. They can hop, hop, hop.

did_you_see_that_rabbit_10.script: The rabbit and kits come down--fast!

did_you_see_that_rabbit_11.script: You can see rabbits out there. You can see rabbits in here.

did_you_see_that_rabbit_12.script: This rabbit will plop down on your lap. You can pet him.

did_you_see_that_rabbit_13.script: Did you see that rabbit? He likes you!

did_you_see_that_rabbit_2.script: Did you see that rabbit? Where did he go?

did_you_see_that_rabbit_4.script: They rip the tops. Their teeth nip and chop.

did_you_see_that_rabbit_6.script: This rabbit hid his hole. He drops plants on top.

did_you_see_that_rabbit_7.script: What is down in the hole? Rabbit kits! A rabbit can have lots of kits.

did_you_see_that_rabbit_8.script: This kit sips milk. That kit hops and flops. The rabbit and kits nap.

did_you_see_that_rabbit_9.script: Rabbits have to look out for the kits. Do you see the rabbit up on the hill? She stops and sits still. She sniffs.

dinosaur_hall_1.script: Calling one, Calling all! Come see what's here at Dinosaur Hall.

dinosaur_hall_10.script: Dinosaur bones can tell us more about the dinosaurs that lived here before.

dinosaur_hall_11.script: Dinosaur teeth and dinosaur jaws. Dinosaur feet and dinosaur claws.

dinosaur_hall_12.script: A dinosaur baby so cute in its nest. Look at that big one! It must be T-Rex!

dinosaur_hall_13.script: Today there are no dinosaurs at all, but you can still see them at Dinosaur Hall.

dinosaur_hall_2.script: Dinosaurs big and dinosaurs small. Dinosaurs, dinosaurs! We have them all!

dinosaur_hall_3.script: Dinosaur maps are here for us all, to show us the way around Dinosaur Hall.

dinosaur_hall_4.script: Dinosaurs long and dinosaurs tall, they are all here at Dinosaur Hall.

dinosaur_hall_5.script: Dinosaurs with plates and dinosaurs with sails. Dinosaurs with spikes up and down their tails.

dinosaur_hall_6.script: Dinosaurs with horns, one, two, three! Is this the dinosaur you came to see?

dinosaur_hall_7.script: Dinosaurs little, dinosaurs so small. Does this one look like a dinosaur at all?

dinosaur_hall_8.script: Dinosaurs with bills, dinosaurs with crests. So many dinosaurs! Come see the rest.

dinosaur_hall_9.script: Dinosaurs eating plants, dinosaurs eating meat. It's a dinosaur show! Come get a seat.

dog_went_for_a_walk_1.script: Dog went for a walk with Jenny.

dog_went_for_a_walk_2.script: Dog went for a walk with Tom.

dog_went_for_a_walk_3.script: Dog went for a walk with David.

dog_went_for_a_walk_4.script: Dog went for a walk with Mom.

dog_went_for_a_walk_5.script: Dog went for a walk with Dad.

donkey_and_monkey_1.script: Donkey and Monkey were friends. They lived by a big lake with a sandy shore. Two trees hid them from the hot sun.

donkey_and_monkey_10.script: Is a low rock wall next to you? Jump up on this wall, but don't fall!

donkey_and_monkey_11.script: Do you see two paths? Follow the path on the left all the way to the end.

donkey_and_monkey_12.script: Now look for a low flat rock. It is between a big and a little tree. Look in the deep grass next to the rock.

donkey_and_monkey_13.script: Donkey and Monkey dashed to the rock. They looked in the tall grass. 'I see it,' said Donkey. 'It's a jar. It says HONEY!'

donkey_and_monkey_14.script: Monkey's father smiled. Then they all sat down and had some tea and honey. Who put the map in the box and the honey in the grass?

donkey_and_monkey_2.script: One day Monkey's father came to visit. They all sat in the shade and had some mint tea. Then they went for a walk along the lake.

donkey_and_monkey_3.script: Monkey's father told some jokes. His jokes were funny. Monkey and Donkey were happy.

donkey_and_monkey_4.script: All of a sudden, Monkey said, Look! I see a little box in the sand. He ran and picked it up.

donkey_and_monkey_5.script: Donkey said, 'We need a key. Maybe the key is in the sand.' So they all looked for the key.

donkey_and_monkey_6.script: 'I see it!' said Monkey's father. He picked up a rusty little key and put it in the keyhole. It unlocked the box.

donkey_and_monkey_7.script: What was inside? A map! 'What do you think we will find if we follow it?', asked Donkey.

donkey_and_monkey_8.script: Seek and look, here and there. Follow this map to show you where. Stand in front of the tree. Look at the lake. Then take ten steps.

donkey_and_monkey_9.script: Now go around the big rock, where you will see two bushes. Go six big steps past them.

drip_drop_drip_2.script: The cats come in. The worms come out. The rain comes down.

drip_drop_drip_3.script: Drip, drop, drip! He likes the rain.

drip_drop_drip_4.script: The rain is here! The cats come in. The worms come out. The rain comes down.

drip_drop_drip_5.script: Drop, drip, drop! She likes the rain.

drip_drop_drip_6.script: The rain is here! The cats ran in. We ran out. We like the rain!

follow_it_1.script: This is Rabbit. Do you want to meet him? He lives in a hole in a big tree on the hill.

follow_it_10.script: How to Make Crow's Plane: Lay the paper out flat. Fold it down the middle. Fold down one corner. Then fold down the other corner.

follow_it_11.script: Now fold the corners one more time. Then fold one side over the other.

follow_it_12.script: Fold down the wing on one side. Then fold down the wing on the other side. Now open up the wings and put tape on the top.

follow_it_13.script: 'Caw, caw, caw,' said Crow. 'Now you are ready to test it.' Did it fly?

follow_it_2.script: He has lots of weeds to hide in and lots of grass to eat. At the bottom of the hill, there is a little lake where Rabbit gets water.

follow_it_3.script: One day Rabbit was going down the hill to the lake. The wind was blowing. There was so much dust that Rabbit could not see.

follow_it_4.script: Rabbit said, 'This wind could blow a little rabbit into the lake. I'm glad I'm big so I don't fall in.'

follow_it_5.script: 'Caw, caw, caw.' Rabbit looked up and saw his friend Crow. Crow liked to play in the wind. It was fun when the wind lifted her up. Rabbit said, 'I wish I could fly like my friend Crow.'

follow_it_6.script: The next day there was snow on the top of the big tree. 'Caw, caw, caw,' Crow said, as she landed on a branch.

follow_it_7.script: Rabbit was feeling sad. 'All I am is a slow rabbit,' he said. 'I cannot fly like you.'

follow_it_8.script: 'You don't have wings and you cannot fly,' said Crow. 'But you can make a little plane to fly.'

follow_it_9.script: 'You need some paper and some tape. I'll show you what to do, one step at a time.'

freda_says_please_1.script: Freda liked to play pretend. She really loved to play school. She was always the teacher -- just like Miss Cathy.

freda_says_please_10.script: 'Line up for recess,' Freda told her bears. She wished Percy would line up, too.

freda_says_please_11.script: Freda walked over to Percy. 'Please line up,' she said. 'Well, okay,' said Percy. 'I will--since you said 'please.''

freda_says_please_12.script: Emma saw Freda and Percy come outside. She and her dog, Pickle, wanted to play. 'Can we join your class?' Emma asked.

freda_says_please_13.script: 'Sure,' said Freda. 'Line up behind Percy.' 'What happened to 'please'?' asked Percy. 'Please,' said Freda.

freda_says_please_14.script: 'Remember that I want to be the teacher, too,' said Percy. 'You can be the recess teacher,' said Freda.

freda_says_please_15.script: 'Thank you,' said Percy. 'Miss Cathy said it's polite to say thank you when someone does something nice for you.'

freda_says_please_16.script: Percy said, 'Okay. Now that I'm the teacher, I say, let's play ball!' He gave the ball to Freda. 'Thank you,' she said.

freda_says_please_17.script: 'I know what Miss Cathy says when someone says 'thank you,'' Emma said. 'You're welcome.'

freda_says_please_18.script: 'Pass the ball to Percy, please,' said Emma. Freda tossed the ball high in the air.

freda_says_please_19.script: Percy ran and caught it. 'Thank you!' Percy called out.

freda_says_please_2.script: 'Sit in a circle,' she told her dolls. 'No running. No shouting,' she told her robots.

freda_says_please_21.script: It's polite to say 'please' when you ask for something, 'thank you' when someone does something nice for you, 'your welcome' when someone thanks you.

freda_says_please_3.script: 'Quiet for story time,' she told her bears.

freda_says_please_4.script: Soon Percy came over. He liked playing school.

freda_says_please_5.script: 'I'm the teacher,' said Freda. 'Okay,' said Percy. 'But I want to be the teacher sometime, too.'

freda_says_please_6.script: 'For now you're a student,' said Freda. 'Lie down. Rest time.'

freda_says_please_7.script: Miss Cathy always says 'Please lie down'' said Percy. 'She told us that it's polite to say 'please' when you ask for something.'

freda_says_please_8.script: 'I'm the teacher!' said Freda. 'I can do what I want.' 'You're being bossy,' said Percy. 'Miss Cathy is always polite.'

freda_says_please_9.script: Percy walked away and began to play by himself.

friends_1.script: Cleo sits on Emily Elizabeth's lap. T-Bone sits on Emily Elizabeth's lap. Clifford does not fit.

friends_2.script: Cleo flips and flops. T-Bone flops and flaps. Emily Elizabeth slips.

friends_3.script: Clifford lifts Cleo up. Clifford lifts T-Bone up. Clifford lifts Emily Elizabeth up. The pals sit on Clifford. It is fun to have friends.

friends_4.script: Cleo is fast. T-Bone is fast. But Clifford runs past.

friends_5.script: Cleo sips. T-Bone dips. Clifford spills.

friends_6.script: Clifford mops and mops. The pals fill it up. It is fun to have friends.

friends_7.script: The hat does not fit Cleo. The hat goes not fit T-Bone. The hat does not fit Emily Elizabeth. It flops. The hat fits Clifford.

friends_8.script: It is fun to have friends.

frogs_10.script: Up they go! Down they go! They hop up on a log. They hop down to a rock. They hop from the rock into a pond.

frogs_11.script: Do frogs like to swim? Yes! Frogs have skin called webs. The webs let frogs swim fast.

frogs_13.script: Frog facts. This frog is big! This frog is not.

frogs_14.script: All frogs are not in ponds. Look up! Frogs have a big sac. They call out, 'Rib-bit!'

frogs_2.script: This is a frog. A frog has two long back legs. Its' eyes stick out and its' skin is wet. All frogs have tongues. No frog has a neck.

frogs_3.script: Where can you see frogs? You can see them where it is wet, where it is hot,

frogs_4.script: and where it is not so hot!

frogs_5.script: What do frogs like to eat? Bugs! Bugs! Bugs! Frogs kill and eat them. A frog flicks out its long tongue. The bug sticks to it.

frogs_6.script: The frog licks its tongue. What a snack!

frogs_7.script: What are tadpoles? All frogs were tadpoles. Tadpoles swim out of frog eggs. They have gills like fish.

frogs_8.script: The tadpoles are not like that for long. They get legs and lungs. They can come up on land. They are frogs!

frogs_9.script: Do frogs like land? Frogs like to hop on land. They kick off with their long back legs.

geraldine_first_10.script: Geraldine didn't want any dessert, so she went to play in her room.

geraldine_first_11.script: Willie came in later to see what she was doing. Geraldine was building a tower with her blocks. Willie built one too.

geraldine_first_12.script: 'Uh-ohhhh,' he cried when his tower toppled onto Geraldine's. 'I'm sure he didn't mean it,' Mama told Geraldine. 'I'll help you make another one,' Papa offered.

geraldine_first_13.script: 'No,' Geraldine said angrily. 'No,' Willie echoed. Geraldine gnashed her teeth. 'Willie, WILL YOU PLEASE STOP COPYING ME!' 'Put away your toys now, Geraldine,' Mama said. 'It's getting late.'

geraldine_first_14.script: In a few minutes Willie heard Geraldine banging around in her room. He peeked in the door. 'What are you doing, Geraldine?' he whispered. 'Cleaning,' Geraldine mumbled, and she picked up some blocks.

geraldine_first_15.script: Willie picked up a block too, and Geraldine groaned. Then she smiled. 'Willie,' she said, 'I have to clean my room. Don't get in the way.'

geraldine_first_16.script: She picked up a few more blocks and waited.

geraldine_first_17.script: 'Now I'll put away the doll's clothes,' she announced loudly.

geraldine_first_18.script: Geraldine picked up a book and a few crayons.

geraldine_first_19.script: But when she started to put away the tea set, Willie didn't budge. 'I'm tired,' He said, and he left. Geraldine laughed. Then she went to find Mama.

geraldine_first_2.script: 'Willie first,' Geraldine called back. 'I'm always first,' Willie cried. 'Not true,' Geraldine shouted.

geraldine_first_20.script: 'I'm ready for my bath,' she said. 'Willie is tired, so I'll be first,' 'Geraldine is first!' Mama proclaimed. 'And first is just fine with me. How about some bubble bath?' Geraldine nodded happily, and Mama took her upstairs.

geraldine_first_3.script: 'Don't shout, Geraldine,' Papa scolded. 'We'll have dinner,' Mama said, and she signed.

geraldine_first_4.script: 'Ugh,' said Geraldine when she came into the kitchen. 'No beans,' 'Beans make you strong,' Papa said. 'I'm strong now,' Geraldine insisted, and she picked up Willie and plopped him into his chair.

geraldine_first_5.script: 'No beans,' Willie said, and he giggled. 'Don't copy me,' Geraldine said.

geraldine_first_6.script: 'Carrots are bad too,' she grumbled, and she took them off her plate. 'Carrots are good for your eyes,' said Papa, and he put them back. 'Maybe if I don't eat them, I won't see Willie,' Geraldine argued, and she made a face.

geraldine_first_7.script: Willie made a face too. 'Stop coping me, Willie,' Geraldine snapped.

geraldine_first_8.script: Geraldine drank her milk and held up the glass to look through the bottom. 'I can see you,' she said to Papa. Willie held up his glass too. 'I can see you, Geraldine,' he said.

geraldine_first_9.script: Geraldine put down her glass with a thud. 'I said don't copy me, Willie!' 'That's enough, Geraldine,' Mama said sternly.

goats_book_1.script: Goat liked to sit by an oak tree and read. The book he liked best was 'Making and Doing Things.'

goats_book_10.script: 1. Ask your friends for a crayon. Tell them you can guess what color it is without looking.

goats_book_11.script: 2. Put your hands behind your back. Rub your fingernail with the crayon. This will leave color on your nail.

goats_book_12.script: 3. Say to your friends, 'I can feel the color with my hand.' Look at your nail, but don't let them see!

goats_book_13.script: 4. Then tell your friends the color. They will not see the color on your nail or guess what you did. They will say, 'What a neat trick!'

goats_book_14.script: That's what Goat's friends said! Now you can try these things too.

goats_book_2.script: Goat liked to make things. He liked to do tricks. The book showed him what to do.

goats_book_3.script: .Goat wanted to make a boat. He looked on pages 22 and 23 of his book. It said, 'How to Make a Boat Out of Soap.'

goats_book_4.script: 1. Get some soap. Will it float? Put it in some water to test it. Now go on to the next step.

goats_book_5.script: 2. Find a stick that is three inches long. This will be the mast. A mast helps the boat sail. Put the mast into the soap.

goats_book_6.script: 3. To make a sail, cut some paper, like this. Then use tape to put the sail on the mast. Your boat is ready to float!

goats_book_7.script: Goat put his boat in the tub. Did it float? No! The boat fell on its side. 'My sail is too big,' said Goat.

goats_book_8.script: So Goat got two cakes of soap and put a rubber band around them. Did the boat float? Yes!

goats_book_9.script: The next day Goat sat down by the oak tree to read his book. He looked on page 46. It said, 'A Neat Trick'.

hairy_maclarys_bone_1.script: Down in the town by the butcher's shop door, sat Hairy Maclary from Donaldson's Dairy.

hairy_maclarys_bone_10.script: They came to a yard full of dinghies and yachts. Round they all went

hairy_maclarys_bone_12.script: They came to a building site, cluttered and stony. Over they went

hairy_maclarys_bone_14.script: They came to a wall by the house of Miss Plum. One of them jumped

hairy_maclarys_bone_16.script: So at last he was free to go home on his own. Hairy Maclary with ALL of his bone.

hairy_maclarys_bone_2.script: Out of the door came Samuel Stone. He gave Hairy Maclary his tastiest bone.

hairy_maclarys_bone_3.script: Then off up the street on scurrying feet, on his way to the dairy went Hairy Maclary.

hairy_maclarys_bone_4.script: And chasing him home with their eyes on the bone, went Hercules Morse, Bottomley Potts, Muffin McLay, Bitzer Maloney and Schnitzel von Krumm with the very low tum.

hairy_maclarys_bone_5.script: Hungrily sniffing and licking their chops, they followed him up past the school and the shops.

hairy_maclarys_bone_6.script: They came to the sign selling Sutherland's Sauce. Through they all went

hairy_maclarys_bone_8.script: They came to a hedge along Waterloo Way. Under they went

he_likes_she_likes_5.script: He likes the ladder. She likes the ladder.

he_likes_she_likes_6.script: He and she like to laugh and laugh.

hen_pens_joke_1.script: Hen Pen was sniffing a rose when something hit her hat. 'My, my!' she said. 'The sky is falling. I must tell Wise King.'

hen_pens_joke_10.script: They went down the path and came upon Fox Lox. 'Wake up!' Hen Pen said. With a poke, Fox Lox woke up.

hen_pens_joke_11.script: 'We are going to tell Wise King the sky is falling,' Hen Pen said. 'No joke?' said Fox Lox. 'Then use the quick path.'

hen_pens_joke_12.script: They went down the path to a wide hole. 'You will get to Wise King,' said Fox Lox. 'Come with me.' But Hen Pen saw the trick.

hen_pens_joke_13.script: Fox Lox went in. Hen Pen did not. 'The joke is on him,' Hen Pen said. 'My, my! Look at all the nice, ripe apples!'

hen_pens_joke_14.script: So Hen Pen, Duck Luck, Chick Quick, and Drake Lake went home to make apple pie. They never did tell Wise King the sky was falling.

hen_pens_joke_2.script: She hiked down the path and came upon Duck Luck. 'Wake up!' Hen Pen said. With a poke, Duck Luck woke up.

hen_pens_joke_3.script: 'The sky is falling,' said Hen Pen. 'I am going to tell Wise King. Can you come too?'

hen_pens_joke_4.script: So side by side, Hen Pen and Duck Luck hiked down the path to tell Wise King the sky was falling. They came upon Chick Quick.

hen_pens_joke_5.script: 'Wake up! The sky is falling,' Hen Pen said. 'We are going to see Wise King. Can you come too?'

hen_pens_joke_6.script: So in a line, Hen Pen, Duck Luck, and Chick Quick went to tell Wise King the sky was falling.

hen_pens_joke_7.script: They hiked down the path and came upon Drake Lake. 'Wake up!' Hen Pen said. With a poke, Drake Lake woke up.

hen_pens_joke_8.script: 'We are going to tell Wise King the sky is falling,' they said. 'Can you come too?'

hen_pens_joke_9.script: So Hen Pen, Duck Luck, Chick Quick, and Drake Lake went miles to tell Wise King the sky was falling.

henrys_happy_birthday_lv1_1.script: 'Wake up, Henry,' said Papa. 'Today is your big day.'

henrys_happy_birthday_lv1_10.script: Henry donned his white shirt. Mama would tie his bowtie. 'There,' she said. 'Now you are ready.'

henrys_happy_birthday_lv1_12.script: The doorbell rang. Henry ran to answer it. It was aunt Sue with cousin Gertie.

henrys_happy_birthday_lv1_13.script: Aunt Sue gave Henry a big birthday kiss that left a sticky red mark on his face.

henrys_happy_birthday_lv1_14.script: Gertie gave him a package in wrapping paper Henry thought was ugly. He knew it couldn't be anything good.

henrys_happy_birthday_lv1_15.script: Henry's best friend, Mark, brought a big yellow box, but Henry could tell from the shape that it wasn't the thing Mark had said. Timmy forgot his present at home.

henrys_happy_birthday_lv1_16.script: When everyone was there, Papa could start the games.

henrys_happy_birthday_lv1_17.script: Molly stuck a tail on Henry's back. Gertie would call him a donkey.

henrys_happy_birthday_lv1_18.script: The prize for musical chairs was a little silver whistle which Henry would have chosen.

henrys_happy_birthday_lv1_19.script: But Timmy would push him off the last chair just as the music would stop. The room quickly became unruly . Everyone tried to find a chair. Henry was miserable. 'No more games,' he said.

henrys_happy_birthday_lv1_2.script: Henry flew out of bed and donned his slippers. He would clear this throat then start to sing. 'Happy birthday to me, happy birthday to me...'

henrys_happy_birthday_lv1_20.script: So Mama brought in the cake. Everyone sat under the bunting and sang 'Happy birthday' as aunt Sue lit the candles. 'One for each year plus one to wish on,' she said cheerfully.

henrys_happy_birthday_lv1_21.script: Henry closed his eyes to blow the candles. I wish, he thought, that this were someone else's birthday. Then he could try hard not to cry.

henrys_happy_birthday_lv1_22.script: Papa came with helium balloons. He had a special party hat for Henry that was like a crown. Everybody clapped.

henrys_happy_birthday_lv1_23.script: Mama cut the cake with a spatula . Henry got the first piece. It was pink and white inside with real whipped cream between the layers. Henry took a bite. It was good. 'Not too plain?' Mama would ask. Henry shook his head.

henrys_happy_birthday_lv1_26.script: Gertie's present was a tiny model fire engine with a siren that really drove. Henry was fond of it.

henrys_happy_birthday_lv1_27.script: When everyone had gone home, Henry sat on Mama's lap. 'Nice party, after all?' Mama asked. Henry shook his head. 'But I didn't make a good birthday wish,' he said.

henrys_happy_birthday_lv1_28.script: Mama gave him a hug. 'Never mind,' she said. 'You have a whole year to think of another one.' Henry smiled. 'Ok,' he said, 'I will.'

henrys_happy_birthday_lv1_7.script: Henry would pick up the shiny, silver-colored basket. He would move it slowly over to Gertie's place. 'Don't forget' Henry said. 'Don't be silly, Henry. I won't.'

in_the_woods_whos_been_here_1.script: It is cool and sunny on this autumn afternoon. The smell of sweet fern is everywhere. 'William, do you want to go for a walk?' asks Cammy. 'Sure,' says William. 'Let's go.'

in_the_woods_whos_been_here_10.script: Cammy finds a blue feather on the trail. Then she finds another one on a leaf and five more under a laurel bush. Who's been here?

in_the_woods_whos_been_here_11.script: A goshawk and a blue jay.

in_the_woods_whos_been_here_12.script: Gray rock breaks up the leaf-covered hillside. Something black catches the children's eyes. It is a small, dark cave. Sam runs ahead and barks at the opening. William stops and grabs his sister's hand. There are bleached bones on the ledge outside the cave. Who's been here?

in_the_woods_whos_been_here_13.script: A family of red foxes and a woodchuck.

in_the_woods_whos_been_here_14.script: William and Cammy stop beside a large gray boulder. Something strange is stuck to the rock. Who's been here?

in_the_woods_whos_been_here_16.script: An orange wood lily stands in a sunny clearing. The flower is almost as tall as Cammy. There is another stalk next to it. But the flower is gone. Who's been here?

in_the_woods_whos_been_here_18.script: Cammy and William follow the path on their way home. The rich smell of sweet fern fills the air again. They find a basket on a blanket under an old apple tree. 'I wonder who's been here?' William asks. But Cammy knows...

in_the_woods_whos_been_here_2.script: The children follow a well-worn path into the woods. They walk under an old cherry tree. They see an empty nest. Who's been here?

in_the_woods_whos_been_here_4.script: Cammy and William come to a big rock. A tree had split it apart, and a flat stone juts out of the tree. Who's been here?

in_the_woods_whos_been_here_6.script: The trail follows an old stone wall. The children and their dog, Sam, climb over it. A clump of milkweed plants grows in the field on the other side. Something hangs from a milkweed leaf. Who's been here?

in_the_woods_whos_been_here_8.script: Cammy and William climb over a smooth gray tree that has fallen across the trail. The bark has been gnawed off the branches close to the ground. Who's been here?

in_the_woods_whos_been_here_title.script: In the Woods: Who's Been Here?

jane_and_jake_bake_a_cake_1.script: 'What a day,' said Jane. 'It is so wet out. What can we do on a day like this?' 'Let's make a cake,' said Jake. 'Make a cake! How?' said Jane.

jane_and_jake_bake_a_cake_10.script: 'I will shake in some of this stuff,' Jake said. 'I will mix in some of that stuff. Yes! I like the taste of my cake.' Jake had a big grin on his face.

jane_and_jake_bake_a_cake_11.script: Jane cut up things for her cake. She still had to mix. She still had to put the cake mix in the pan. 'Ha!' said Jake. 'I am all set to bake my cake.'

jane_and_jake_bake_a_cake_12.script: 'What is that?' he said. 'I see one more thing I could use. GUM! I like the taste of this pink gum. It will go in my cake,' Jake said. 'Now I can bake.'

jane_and_jake_bake_a_cake_13.script: 'I put my cake in to bake,' Jake said to Jane. 'Get the plates!' 'Look at this place,' said Jane. 'It is a mess!' POP! 'What was that?' said Jake. 'It came from your cake,' said Jane.

jane_and_jake_bake_a_cake_14.script: 'Look out!' said Jake. The cake gave a shake. POP! POP! POP! Jake had cake on his face. So did Jane. 'What was in that cake?' said Jane. 'Gum,' said Jake. 'Yum,' said Jane. So the apes ate all the cake!

jane_and_jake_bake_a_cake_2.script: 'You just mix this and that and bake,' Jake said. 'We are smart apes. We can do it.'

jane_and_jake_bake_a_cake_3.script: Jane got a book from the shelf. 'Let's look in this book first,' Jane said. 'It will tell us how to make a cake.'

jane_and_jake_bake_a_cake_4.script: Jake made a face. 'That will take so long,' he said. 'This is not a race,' said Jane. 'I like to race,' said Jake. 'I like to do things fast.' 'I will not rush,' said Jane.

jane_and_jake_bake_a_cake_5.script: 'We have two pans and many, many eggs,' Jake said. 'We can each make a cake.'

jane_and_jake_bake_a_cake_6.script: 'You can take as long as you like,' Jake said to Jane. 'I will race on. I will make my cake first!' 'But how will your cake taste?' said Jane.

jane_and_jake_bake_a_cake_7.script: 'Let's look at the book,' Jane said to Jake. 'Crack two eggs in a cup. Add a cup of milk.'

jane_and_jake_bake_a_cake_8.script: 'Too late,' said Jake. 'I have put in my eggs and milk. I am fast, fast, fast. Hmmm. I see a can of pop,' said Jake. 'I can shake the can. I can add fizz to my cake.'

jane_and_jake_bake_a_cake_9.script: 'I have two cups that are the same,' Jane said. 'First I will fill one cup from this bag. I will fill the other cup from that bag. Then I will mix each cup in.'

jane_and_jake_bake_a_cake_title.script: Jane and Jake Bake a Cake

jazz_class_1.script: 'Liz! Mom! Let's go!' said Jan. 'Where?' said Liz. 'We have to go by cab,' Jan's Mom said. 'Where?' said Liz.

jazz_class_10.script: 'When I hear jazz, I go, go, go!'

jazz_class_13.script: 'What do you like?' said Jan. Liz said, 'I like ballet.' 'You do? said Jan.

jazz_class_14.script: 'I like ballet and jazz,' said Liz. 'Yes!' said Jan.

jazz_class_2.script: 'There!' said Jan. 'There's my jazz class. Let's go!'

jazz_class_3.script: 'What is jazz?' said Liz. 'This is jazz,' said Jan. 'I bop. I bob.'

jazz_class_9.script: 'When I hear jazz, I jam, jam, jam!'

left_right_emma_1.script: Emma liked to march. She marched in her bedroom. She marched to the bathroom.

left_right_emma_10.script: Freda, Carlos, and Mr.D. stepped behind Emma on the right.

left_right_emma_11.script: 'Now, start with your left foot,' said Miss Cathy. 'Which one is that?' Emma whispered. 'This one,' said Freda, as she tapped Emma's left knee.

left_right_emma_12.script: 'Now, your right foot,' said Miss Cathy. 'Forward, march! Left! Right! Left! Right!'

left_right_emma_13.script: Emma still wasn't sure which way was left and which way was right. Miss Cathy took a red string from her pocket and tied it on Emma's right arm.

left_right_emma_14.script: 'This will help you remember,' she explained. 'I get it!' said Percy. 'The red string means right, and no string means left.'

left_right_emma_15.script: They started to march. 'Now, my line will turn left,' said Miss Cathy.

left_right_emma_16.script: 'Your line will turn right,' Miss Cathy added. 'Red string means right,' thought Emma. Both lines turned perfectly.

left_right_emma_17.script: Every night, Emma practiced at home. Pickle helped her. 'Left! Right! Left! Right!' said Emma. They marched all around the house.

left_right_emma_18.script: It was finally Grandparents Day. 'This time, make one long line behind Emma. Now, start with your left foot,' Miss Cathy said.

left_right_emma_19.script: Emma didn't need to look at her red string anymore.

left_right_emma_2.script: Her dog, Pickle, marched behind her.

left_right_emma_20.script: The band marched and played. They turned left. They turned right. All the grandparents stood up and cheered. Pickle wagged his tail--from left to right!

left_right_emma_21.script: Left. Right. Left hand. Right hand. Left foot. Right foot.

left_right_emma_3.script: At school everyone was preparing for Grandparents' Day. Emma's class was forming a marching band. Miss Cathy asked, 'Who wants to be the leader?'

left_right_emma_4.script: Lots of hands went up, but not Emma's. Emma wanted to be the leader, but she wasn't sure she could do it.

left_right_emma_5.script: Miss Cathy could tell that Emma wanted to try. 'How about you, Emma?' asked Miss Cathy. 'You would make a fine leader.'

left_right_emma_6.script: Emma thought for a minute. 'Okay,' she said. 'I'll do my best.'

left_right_emma_7.script: 'Let's make two lines,' said Miss Cathy. 'One on the left behind me.'

left_right_emma_8.script: 'And the other line,' she added, 'will be on the right behind Emma.'

left_right_emma_9.script: 'Come on, Ajay and Camille,' said Percy. 'Let's line up on the left behind Miss Cathy.'

mice_on_ice_1.script: Two cute mice were in their beds, side by side. Then the sun came up. It was a new day. CRACK! The mice woke up. 'What was that?' said one. 'Let's find out!' said the other.

mice_on_ice_10.script: Now the mice were at a big wide pond. They went and got skates. 'Look at me glide', said one. 'Look at me jump', said the other.

mice_on_ice_11.script: 'Look at us!' said the mice. 'We are so cute!' The mice spun on their skates. They were fast, fast, fast... Flip! Mice on ice!

mice_on_ice_12.script: The mice ran back to their tree. 'Look at all that long, long ice' said one. 'Let's take a lick,' said the other.

mice_on_ice_13.script: One of the mice hit part of the long ice. The ice broke off. 'Quick!' said the mice. Crash! Mice on ice!

mice_on_ice_14.script: Now it was late in the day. The sun went down. 'My nose is as red as a rose!' said one of the mice. 'My hands are as cold as ice!' said the other. 'Time to go home,' they said.

mice_on_ice_15.script: The mice took off their new hats and boots. They got back in bed, side by side. 'Ice is nice,' said the mice, 'but home is twice as nice!'

mice_on_ice_2.script: The mice were out of bed, fast! They got up on a box. 'Look!' said one.'Yikes!' said the other. 'Ice! Ice! Ice!' said the mice.

mice_on_ice_3.script: They put on their new hats. They put on their new boots. Then the mice went out. 'Look what broke off the pine tree,' said one. 'Let me see,' said the other.

mice_on_ice_4.script: The mice slid down. They could not stop. Plop! Mice on ice!

mice_on_ice_5.script: The mice ran off to find their sled. 'Take this rope,' said one. 'Here we go!' said the other.

mice_on_ice_6.script: The sled shot over the ice. The mice wove in and out of the trees. They rode for a mile. Then they came to a log. The sled went over the top. The mice did not. Flop! Mice on ice!

mice_on_ice_7.script: The mice got back up. 'Look, there is Fox,' said one. 'He can run fast over the ice!' 'Fox, fox!' yelled the mice. 'Take us for a ride.' Fox gave the mice a big, wide smile. 'I will take you for a ride,' he said. 'Use my tail.'

mice_on_ice_8.script: 'Oh no!' said one. 'Let go!' said the other. Spill! Mice on ice!

mice_on_ice_9.script: 'That was close!' said one of the mice. 'It was no joke!' said the other.

ord_eats_a_pizza_12.script: 'Hey!' says Max. 'We all can make it.'

ord_eats_a_pizza_15.script: And in the blink of a dragon's eye, they make a dragon pizza pie!

ord_eats_a_pizza_16.script: Good job, Emmy, Wheezie, Zak! Good job, Cassie!

ord_eats_a_pizza_4.script: What goes on a pizza pie?

ord_eats_a_pizza_5.script: Zak says, 'Horseflies go on top, with earmuffs, drums, and green gumdrops!'

ord_eats_a_pizza_6.script: Wheezie says, 'No, a flute and horn, with fairy shoes and pink popcorn!'

ord_eats_a_pizza_7.script: Horseflies, flutes, and horns? Oh, my! Is this what goes on pizza pie?

ord_eats_a_pizza_8.script: Let's ask Cassie! She might know what goes best on pizza dough.

ord_eats_a_pizza_9.script: Cassie knows just who to ask.

paper_bag_trail_1.script: Lee ate some popcorn and threw the bag away.

paper_bag_trail_2.script: The wind picked it up and blew it away.

paper_bag_trail_3.script: The dog picked it up and took it away.

paper_bag_trail_4.script: The ants picked it up and dragged it away.

paper_bag_trail_5.script: The bird picked it up and carried it away.

paper_bag_trail_6.script: The rain picked it up and washed it away.

paper_bag_trail_7.script: Guess what Lee did? Lee picked it up and threw it away, again!

paws_and_claws_1.script: What are paws? What are claws? Paws are animal feet with claws.

paws_and_claws_10.script: This panda bear uses its claws to get grass to eat.

paws_and_claws_11.script: Black bears use their claws to grip and crawl up trees. Their claws help them steal sweets from the bees.

paws_and_claws_12.script: Paws leave prints called tracks. Tracks can tell us which animals were around and where they went. Where did this bear go?

paws_and_claws_13.script: Can you tell what animals left these tracks?

paws_and_claws_2.script: Claws are like your nails. Some are very long. Some are not. Claws are sharp.

paws_and_claws_3.script: Cats and bears have claws. Birds have claws too. Their claws are called talons.

paws_and_claws_4.script: Most birds have very sharp claws. Claws help birds grip and hold on to things.

paws_and_claws_5.script: Birds use their claws to catch and hold food. This bird dives and grabs for fish.

paws_and_claws_6.script: Big cats hunt with paws and claws. Thick pads on their paws help them sneak up on things.

paws_and_claws_7.script: Most cats can pull their claws in and flick them out. The claws of a cheetah stay out all the time.

paws_and_claws_8.script: Cats like to scratch things. This cat scratches a tree to keep its claws sharp.

paws_and_claws_9.script: Bears have very big paws with sharp claws. They use them to do many things.

pete_the_cat_too_cool_for_school_1.script: Pete wants to look cool. He asks everyone, 'What should I wear?'

pete_the_cat_too_cool_for_school_10.script: 'Wear the shorts with the fish,' Pete's friend Callie says. 'They are my favorite.'

pete_the_cat_too_cool_for_school_12.script: 'Wear the polka-dot socks,' the bus driver says. 'They are my favorite.'

pete_the_cat_too_cool_for_school_14.script: 'Wear the cowboy boots,' Grumpy Toad says. 'They are my favorite.'

pete_the_cat_too_cool_for_school_16.script: 'Wear the tie with the stripes,' Emma says. 'It is my favorite.'

pete_the_cat_too_cool_for_school_18.script: 'Wear your baseball hat,' his coach says. 'It is my favorite.'

pete_the_cat_too_cool_for_school_2.script: 'Wear your yellow shirt,' his mom says. 'It is my favorite.'

pete_the_cat_too_cool_for_school_20.script: Pete puts on all the clothes. Does he look cool?

pete_the_cat_too_cool_for_school_23.script: Pete goes home. He changes his clothes.

pete_the_cat_too_cool_for_school_24.script: Pete puts on HIS favorite shirt. Pete puts on HIS favorite pants.

pete_the_cat_too_cool_for_school_25.script: Pete puts on HIS favorite socks. Pete puts on HIS favorite shoes. Pete puts on his sunglasses.

pete_the_cat_too_cool_for_school_27.script: If you want to be cool, just be you!

pete_the_cat_too_cool_for_school_4.script: 'Wear your red shirt,' Pete's friend Marty says. 'It is my favorite.'

pete_the_cat_too_cool_for_school_6.script: 'Wear your blue shirt,' Pete's brother Bob says. 'It is my favorite.'

pete_the_cat_too_cool_for_school_8.script: 'Wear your long pants,' Pete's teacher says. 'They are my favorite.'

pete_the_cat_too_cool_for_school_title.script: Pete the Cat: Too Cool for School

pizza_cook_1.script: Do you want to eat pizza? Yes! We want pizza! Let's go get some pizza!

pizza_cook_10.script: He rolls it and rolls it. It gets very flat and round. He flips it and spins it. Now it looks like a pizza!

pizza_cook_11.script: Dan puts the cheese and the meat on the pizza. It looks good! Is it time to eat? No. It's time to cook the pizza.

pizza_cook_12.script: The pizza bakes in a big oven. It takes a while to cook. The pizza man takes a look. They cook it some more.

pizza_cook_13.script: Here is our pizza! There is some for me. There is some for you. The pizza man is a good cook!

pizza_cook_14.script: Pizza man, pizza man, Cook the pizza as fast as you can. Pizza man, pizza man, Cook the pizza with Dan. Pizza man, pizza man, Look! The pizza is in the pan. Pizza man, pizza man, We eat pizza as fast as we can!

pizza_cook_2.script: We go to a pizza restaurant. They make good pizza. How do they cook pizza? Come, let's go see!

pizza_cook_3.script: A man shows us where to sit. He gives us a menu. It tells us what we can have. He says, 'What do you want?'

pizza_cook_4.script: We want pizza! We want pizza with meat! We want pizza with cheese!

pizza_cook_5.script: How do they cook pizza? Come, let's look. This is Kwaku. He is the pizza man.

pizza_cook_6.script: It takes work to make a pizza. Dan helps the pizza man. He cuts the meat. He grates the cheese.

pizza_cook_7.script: Kwaku uses a cookbook. He makes a list He puts out all the things. Now he makes the crust.

pizza_cook_8.script: He needs a cup of this. He needs two cups of that. He needs a lot of this. He needs lots and lots of that!

pizza_cook_9.script: He mixes it all around. He mixes and mixes. It gets very, very thick. Now he can make the pizza.

possum_and_the_peeper_lv1_1.script: Peep! Peep! Peep! Possum opened one small eye. What was that noise? He buried his head deeper in his warm winter nest.

possum_and_the_peeper_lv1_11.script: 'AH HA!' they cried, squinting at a small spot on the bank. 'How could such a speck of a thing make such a huge racket?' asked the bear. 'You have woken up the entire forest with all that clamor , little frog,' said Possum. The little peeper looked up, from the possum to the muskrat to the catbirds and finally to the bear.

possum_and_the_peeper_lv1_12.script: Then he puffed out his tiny throat.  It made him look round and rotund.

possum_and_the_peeper_lv1_12_1.script: 'Rise and shine!' he shouted. 'Shake a leg! Build your nests and clean your burrows! It's spring! It's spring! It's spring!' The bear stepped closer to the little frog. 'I,' he growled, 'don't like to be awakened this early in the year, especially,' he added, 'by a frog.'

possum_and_the_peeper_lv1_13.script: 'Oh, but look at the beautiful spring flowers,' cried the peeper, 'and sniff the good spring smells. I won't sleep through such a glorious spring day.' The animals looked around at the budding trees. They inhaled the smell of the blooming flowers and felt the warm sunshine.

possum_and_the_peeper_lv1_13_1.script: They listened to the buzzing bees and warbling birds. Legs stretched and bellies rumbled. It was quite true. No one could deny that it was a fine thing indeed to be out and about on the first warm day of spring.

possum_and_the_peeper_lv1_14.script: 'There's nothing quite like a good walk on a spring morning,' proclaimed Possum. 'Won't you join us for breakfast, little peeper?' But the rotund peeper was already peeping again at the top of his lungs. 'Time for breakfast! Toast and tea! The early bird gets the worm!' Peep! Peep! Peep!

possum_and_the_peeper_lv1_2.script: Peep! Peep! Peep! 'I'll never get back to sleep with all the racket,' he said. 'I will find out who's so inconsiderate, so early in the spring.' Possum emerged from his home and stepped out into the cool, green morning.

possum_and_the_peeper_lv1_3.script: Peep! Peep! Peep! Possum looked up. A pair of catbirds built their nest high in a tree among the new leaves. 'Is that you there?' demanded Possum. 'Not us,' said the catbirds. 'We can scarcely hear ourselves sing with all that clamor.'

possum_and_the_peeper_lv1_4.script: 'Well, I will go see for myself who's making such an awful din.' 'We'll come, too.' said the catbirds. 'We can search high in the trees while you look low on the ground.' They set off towards the woods at the crest of the hill.

possum_and_the_peeper_lv1_5.script: Possum stopped to inhale the scent of trout lilies blooming along the path. Peep! Peep! Peep! They followed the noise up a hill.

possum_and_the_peeper_lv1_6.script: At the crest of the hill stood a bear blinking blearily outside his cave.

possum_and_the_peeper_lv1_6_1.script: 'Who woke me from my warm winter sleep?' he snarled with his long white teeth. 'Was it YOU?' he said, spying Possum. 'No,' said Possum, 'but we are on our way to find out who it was.' 'I had better come along then,' growled the bear. 'You may need someone of my size when you find this fellow.

possum_and_the_peeper_lv1_7.script: They continued over the hill, the catbirds flying overhead, the bear grumbling along behind. The spring sun shone down warm on their feathers and fur. Peep! Peep! Peep! The sound got louder and louder.

possum_and_the_peeper_lv1_8.script: They came down to a marsh where they saw a muskrat spring-cleaning his house. 'Excuse us!' shouted Possum. 'Have you been the peeper?' 'What?' yelled the muskrat. He emerged from his house. 'I can't hear you over all that noise!' 'Well, we're on our way to put a stop to it once and for all,' said the bear, 'if you could show us the way through this swamp.'

possum_and_the_peeper_lv1_9.script: They pressed on to follow the muskrat. They peered between the green reeds and into dark pools. Closer and closer. Louder and louder.
