raccoon_on_his_own_1.script: In the dark swamp, a new day dawned like a sleepy eye, opening slowly. A small wooden boat floated, nudged against some mud.

raccoon_on_his_own_10.script: It was a great big alligator that had been hiding under the lily pads.

raccoon_on_his_own_11.script: 'Zweet, zweet, zweet,' came a sound from above. The raccoon looked up and saw five young warblers. 'Zweet, zweet, zweet,' the birds called down. The raccoon 'churred' back.

raccoon_on_his_own_12.script: Three tiny turtles swam up to the boat. The raccoon reached into the water to touch one turtle's shell, and all three scattered away.

raccoon_on_his_own_13.script: A mother merganser paddled by, leading her nine little ducklings. The raccoon watched the ducklings swimming close to their mother.

raccoon_on_his_own_14.script: Suddenly, the boat bumped into another mud bank and stopped. The raccoon saw his family coming to meet him. He ran to his mother.

raccoon_on_his_own_15.script: And just like that, they were all together again. Downstream.

raccoon_on_his_own_2.script: The mud was soft and sandy. A mother raccoon with her young came to dig and search for food.

raccoon_on_his_own_3.script: Mother found a crunchy crawfish. Two of the young raccoons dug for crawfish near the boat. The third young raccoon was not hungry. He wanted to climb.

raccoon_on_his_own_4.script: The hungry raccoons quickly dug up all the mud around the boat. With no sticky mud to hold it, the boat began to float away.

raccoon_on_his_own_5.script: The raccoon in the boat looked up. A chill ran down his spine. He was drifting in the boat, alone. He was on his own for the very first time. Afraid to jump into the dark water, he stared back at the mud bank. The boat silently carried him downstream.

raccoon_on_his_own_6.script: The raccoon reached up to grab a sturdy branch and climb out of the moving boat. But the branch was too high.

raccoon_on_his_own_7.script: The boat glided under another branch. This branch was low enough to climb. But the raccoon saw the shape of a long snake draped across the branch, and he ducked down.

raccoon_on_his_own_8.script: He crawled to the other end of the boat. Downstream, he saw shadowy shapes of plants and trees sticking up out of the water. The raccoon looked down into the dark stream and saw a raccoon looking back! His reflection kept him company as the boat moved along, through air so still, on water so smooth.

raccoon_on_his_own_9.script: As the boat passed through a bunch of water lilies, something huge made a great splash.

robs_shop_1.script: Hi! I am Rob. This is my shop. I live on top.

robs_shop_10.script: More and more people come in. They ask for things. They get this and that. I pack their bags. I stuff their packs. They hand me cash.

robs_shop_12.script: At six I stop. I look at my shop. Have I done all my jobs? Is there more I could do?

robs_shop_13.script: I look at my list. Yes, there is more than this. There is one more job. Shut the shop and go up top!

robs_shop_2.script: I have lots of jobs to do. What are my jobs? I will tell you.

robs_shop_3.script: I get up at six each day. I go down to unlock my shop. Come in and look!

robs_shop_4.script: Would you like milk? Would you like ham? Would you like nuts or gum or jam? I could sell them all to you!

robs_shop_5.script: I fill my shop. I get out sacks and big bags. I stack cans on top of cans. I stock the racks with lots of things.

robs_shop_6.script: Then I check the shop. If there is a spill, I mop it up. I dust here and there. I brush things into my dustpan.

robs_shop_8.script: People come into my shop. Then I rush, rush, rush! I make them buns with gobs of jam. I make big, thick subs. I make them ham and eggs. I make corn on the cob.

robs_shop_9.script: People like the things I make.

see_the_sea_1.script: We took a trip to the beach. We wanted to see the sea.

see_the_sea_10.script: Back at the dock Ted waved, and we all said good-bye. 'Come back one day,' he said. 'I am glad that you came by.'

see_the_sea_2.script: Captain Ted was at the dock. He called, 'Come sail with me.'

see_the_sea_3.script: 'I must tell you, fish are fast. Keep your eye on the water for what swims past.'

see_the_sea_4.script: 'Look over there at the flashes of green. It's fast fish in their school, too quick to be seen.'

see_the_sea_5.script: We looked at the fish until a big fish swam past. It ate eight fish at once. Small fish must swim fast!

see_the_sea_6.script: This sawfish has a jaw like a saw, but it's not for sawing wood. It uses its jaw to dig things up. It would not saw wood if it could.

see_the_sea_7.script: We saw two starfish, too. One had four arms, not five. It will grow more. It can heal. That's how starfish survive. Far away we could see a fin swim up and back. Ted turned his wheel and said, 'We will not be its snack!'

see_the_sea_8.script: 'Over there are blue whale tails. I see one, two, three. Oh, what tales whales could tell of life under the sea.'

see_the_sea_9.script: 'Did you hear that?' asked Ted. 'Here are seals in the sun. They swim and eat and sleep all day. Life for them must be fun.'

small_animals_with_big_names_1.script: This book is about small animals that have BIG names. Some jump. Some crawl. Some swim in the sea.

small_animals_with_big_names_10.script: The grasshopped jumped on the leaf. Can you find it?

small_animals_with_big_names_11.script: hum-ming-bird. Hummingbirds are the smallest birds. Some are less than three inches long. Hummingbird wings flap so fast they 'hum.'

small_animals_with_big_names_12.script: The hummingbird sipped from the flower with its long bill.

small_animals_with_big_names_13.script: an-cho-vy. An anchovy is a small fish with lots of bones. Anchovies swim around in schools. They are very fast.

small_animals_with_big_names_14.script: The school of anchovies flashed by in the water.

small_animals_with_big_names_15.script: zy-zo-mys. This is a funny word to spell and say. A zyzomys is a little rat. Sometimes it is called a rock rat. The zyzomi looked for food.

small_animals_with_big_names_16.script: ape. What is this? This is not a small animal! We will save it for a new book. What will that book be named?

small_animals_with_big_names_3.script: You can read their names if you do it just a little bit at a time.

small_animals_with_big_names_5.script: ar-ma-dil-lo. Some armadillos are six inches long. They have skin that feels like a bone. They have small legs but they are fast.

small_animals_with_big_names_6.script: The armadillo raced to the tree. Go, armadillo, go!

small_animals_with_big_names_7.script: sal-a-man-der. Salamanders live in tree trunks, in caves, or under rocks. They eat slugs, snails, and other small animals.

small_animals_with_big_names_8.script: The spotted salamander chased the bug.

small_animals_with_big_names_9.script: grass-hop-per. Some grasshoppers can grow to be five inches long. The baby ones don't have wings. All grasshoppers can hop!

stop_the_tot_1.script: 'Hi! Hi! Hi!' I see the tot.

stop_the_tot_10.script: 'Dot! Dot! Dot!' I see a lot of dots on the tot.

stop_the_tot_11.script: The tot likes dots. I do not. No, no, tot. No dots on me! Pop, stop the tot!

stop_the_tot_13.script: I am mad. The tot is sad. She is sad and I am sad.

stop_the_tot_14.script: 'Yes! Yes! Yes!' I like you, tot. I am not mad.

stop_the_tot_3.script: Is the tot in the pot?

stop_the_tot_4.script: Yes, I see the tot. The tot is in the pot.

stop_the_tot_5.script: Oh, no! The pot is on the tot. Pop, stop the tot!

stop_the_tot_7.script: See the tot. She is on top of me. Mom, stop the tot!

stop_the_tot_9.script: I see the tot. I see a dot on the tot.

t_bone_on_top_1.script: See Mom. See Dad. See the tot. The tot likes balloons a lot.

t_bone_on_top_2.script: Up! Up! Up! See a lot of balloons go up.

t_bone_on_top_3.script: Pop! Pop! Pop! The tot is sad. Dad pats the tot.

the_big_nut_1.script: A van went by. BUMP! 'Quack! Quack!' said Duck. 'Stop! Stop!' Pig and Pup ran out. 'What is up, Duck?' they said.

the_big_nut_10.script: 'I'll cut this nut with my bill,' said Duck. 'Yes, I will.' 'What bad luck. My bill is stuck! Quick! Call the vet!' Pig said, 'You bet!'

the_big_nut_11.script: 'Would you come see Duck? Quick!' said Pig. 'Is Duck sick?' said the vet. 'No,' said Pig. 'Duck is not ill. But his bill is stuck in a nut!'

the_big_nut_12.script: The vet ran into the hut. 'Tut-tut!' she said. 'What a nut!' She put her hand

the_big_nut_13.script: The vet ran into the hut. 'Tut-tut!' she said. 'What a nut!' She put a hand in her vest. 'I'll use these,' said the vet. 'I will yank out your bill.'

the_big_nut_14.script: 'Now I'll crack the nut,' said the vet. 'How?' said Duck. 'This is how,' said the vet.

the_big_nut_15.script: The vet went up to the top. She sent the nut down. The nut hit a big rock. Crack!

the_big_nut_16.script: 'What a doc!' said Duck. 'Quack! What is in that nut?'

the_big_nut_17.script: 'Milk,' said the vet. 'Would you like some?' 'We would,' said Pig, Pup, and Duck. So they all went into the hut. They all drank from the nut!

the_big_nut_2.script: 'That van hit a rut,' said Duck. 'This big nut fell out. Would you help me? Let's get it into the hut.'

the_big_nut_3.script: 'What a big nut!' said Pig. 'How will we get it into the hut?' 'Quack! Quack!' said Duck. 'We can use my quilt as a sack.'

the_big_nut_4.script: 'This is a big nut!' said Pup. 'What will you do with it?' 'I'll crack it in two,' Duck said. 'How?' said Pup.

the_big_nut_5.script: Duck put his quilt on the nut. 'How will I crack it? I'll sit and sit,' said Duck.

the_big_nut_6.script: 'Quack!' said Duck. 'I can't crack it.' 'Do not quit!' said Pup.

the_big_nut_7.script: 'Quack! Quack! I'll hit the nut. I'll get this nut to crack,' said Duck. 'Quack!' said Duck. 'I can't crack it.' 'Do not quit!' said Pig.

the_big_nut_8.script: 'I'll hop, hop, hop. I'll get this nut to pop,' said Duck. 'Quack!' said Duck. 'I can't crack it.' 'Do not quit!' said Pig and Pup.

the_big_nut_9.script: 'Quack! Quack! Quack!' said Duck. 'This nut will not crack. Not when I hop or hit. Not when I sit and sit.' 'Do not quit!' said Pup and Pig.

the_frog_trail_1.script: 'What can I play in the rain?' Sam asked his father. 'It is raining just a little bit,' said his father. 'Let's take a walk.'

the_frog_trail_10.script: Sam waited and waited. In five weeks the tadpoles had legs. 'When will they be frogs?' Sam asked.

the_frog_trail_11.script: 'Wait and see,' said his father. The next time Sam an this father went back to the lake, they saw lots of little frogs!

the_frog_trail_2.script: Sam and his father came to a trail. 'Where does the trail go?' asked Sam. 'Wait and see,' said his father.

the_frog_trail_3.script: Then Sam saw tracks in the mud. 'What made these tracks?' he asked. 'Wait and see,' said his father.

the_frog_trail_4.script: Sam and his father saw that the tracks made a trail. The trail went all the way to the lake.

the_frog_trail_5.script: The boy and his father went to the shore of the lake. 'Look! It's a frog!' said Sam. 'I think the frog made the tracks.'

the_frog_trail_6.script: 'Those little black spots are frog eggs,' Sam's father said. 'Frogs lay eggs in the lake.'

the_frog_trail_7.script: 'When will the eggs turn into frogs?' asked Sam. 'Wait and see,' said his father. 'Will the mother raise the eggs?' Sam asked. 'No, Sam. The eggs will grow without help.'

the_frog_trail_8.script: 'Can we stay and see the eggs turn into frogs?' Sam asked. 'It won't happen today, Sam. We will come back to see them.'

the_frog_trail_9.script: Sam waited. In two weeks there were tadpoles by the shore. 'They have tails!' said Sam.

the_hungry_toad_1.script: There was once a toad named Toad.

the_hungry_toad_10.script: The doctor was mad. 'Give me your list,' she said. 'I must add something to it! Do not eat soap, toasters, foam footballs'

the_hungry_toad_11.script: The next day Toad ate and ate, but he was still hungry. He met his friend. Gulp! Toad ate her coat.

the_hungry_toad_12.script: The doctor was very mad! 'What toad eats coats? No one eats coats,' she groaned.

the_hungry_toad_13.script: The next day Toad ate and ate, but he was still hungry. He looked around. He saw a rowboat. He checked his list.

the_hungry_toad_14.script: 'A boat is not on my list,' he said. 'Can I eat a boat?' 'Nope, I'd better not.'

the_hungry_toad_2.script: Toad was always hungry. He ate and ate and ate, but he always wanted more.

the_hungry_toad_3.script: Like most toads, he could puff out his throat to croak. His throat could get very, very big.

the_hungry_toad_4.script: One day Toad ate and ate, but he was still hungry. Then he saw a bar of soap. Gulp! It got stuck in his throat.

the_hungry_toad_5.script: Toad hopped down the road to see the doctor. 'A toad does not eat soap,' said the doctor as she took it out.

the_hungry_toad_6.script: The next day Toad ate and ate, but he was still hungry. He saw a toaster. Gulp! It got stuck in his throat.

the_hungry_toad_7.script: The doctor said, 'Toads do not eat toasters, and toads do not eat soap! I will make a list for you. Don't eat these things again!'

the_hungry_toad_9.script: The next day Toad ate and ate, but he was still hungry. He went to the park. Gulp! Toad ate a big foam football!

the_kind_child_1.script: 'I'll stay with your baby girl,' the grandmother said to the little girl's mother. 'I am not a baby,' the girl said. 'I am a very big kid.'

the_kind_child_10.script: 'I had a very nice time with you. I love you Gram,' the little girl said with a smile.

the_kind_child_11.script: 'When can you come back?' she asked Gram. Gram said she would be back soon.

the_kind_child_12.script: Gram gave the little girl a kiss. The little girl gave Gram a hug. 'I know you would like to play with your friends,' Gram said. 'It means a lot to me that you are here with your old Gram. You are a kind child.'

the_kind_child_2.script: Then she asked her mom if she could go and play with her friends. Her mother just gave her a look.

the_kind_child_3.script: When the little girl turned on the TV, her Gram said, 'Let's not look at TV. Would you like to find a book we can read together?'

the_kind_child_4.script: After reading for a while, Gram asked the little girl, 'Shall I stop now?' 'No, don't stop. Do you mind?' the little girl said. Gram did not mind at all.

the_kind_child_5.script: When it was time for lunch, Gram made two sandwiches and some fresh lemonade. Then she cut an apple in half.

the_kind_child_6.script: 'Before we eat, you must find a star in your lunch,' Gram told the little girl. 'There are no stars out now. It's daytime!' the girl said. 'Just look,' said Gram.

the_kind_child_7.script: First, the girl looked in the glass of lemonade. Next, she looked inside her sandwich. She could not find a star.

the_kind_child_8.script: Then Gram held up the apple and showed her the star. 'See, it was there all the time,' she said.

the_kind_child_9.script: 'Now let's be a little wild and eat our lunch outside,' said Gram. They took their lunch and went out the back door. 'Lunch tastes good outside!' the little girl said. They sang songs. The little girl told Gram jokes. Gram said the jokes were funny. Then they played Go Fish.

the_pancake_man_1.script: 'Wake up! Wake up!' said the Dog, the Cat, the Pig, and the Hen. 'I will,' said the Little Old Woman. 'I will get out of bed and make a big pancake.' She made a pancake with a face of gumdrops.

the_pancake_man_2.script: All of a sudden, the pancake man jumped off the plate. The woman ran after him. He waved and said, 'Run, run as fast as you can! You can't catch me, I'm the Pancake Man!'

the_pancake_man_3.script: The Dog and the Cat sat in the shade. The Pancake Man came up to them. 'Stop! We want to taste that pancake,' they said. 'Too late,' said the Pancake Man. 'I ran from the Little Old Woman and I can run from you. I can!'

the_pancake_man_4.script: Then the Pancake Man met the Pig. 'I will take you back to the Little Old Woman,' the Pig said. 'Then shake a leg,' said the Pancake Man. 'I ran from the Little Old Woman, the Dog, and the Cat, and I can run from you. I can!'

the_pancake_man_5.script: The Hen was on the gate when the Pancake Man came by. 'Shame on you,' said the Hen. 'Look at all the fuss! I will get you!' 'No! I ran from the Little Old Woman, the Dog, the Cat, and the Pig, and I can run from you. I can!' said the Pancake Man.

the_pancake_man_6.script: The Pancake Man then ran to a lake. A Fox came up to him and said, 'Don't get wet! I will take you. Jump on.' Out on the lake, the Fox said, 'Now jump on my nose!' The Pancake Man did. Was this a mistake?

the_pancake_man_7.script: No! The Fox had a picnic set up. 'Am I about to be your lunch?' asked the Pancake Man. 'I don't like pancakes,' said the Fox. 'But I do like grape jam sandwiches.' So they ate and ate. This is the end of the tale, but not the end of the Pancake Man!

the_street_band_1.script: There once was a dog. 'I am too weak to work. My man does not need me,' he said.

the_street_band_10.script: 'I need sleep,' Cat said. 'I need a seat,' Bird said.

the_street_band_11.script: 'I see a hut!' Cat said. So Dog, Sheep, Cat, and Bird went to peek in the hut.

the_street_band_12.script: There were mean men in the hut who liked to steal. They were eating a big meal. 'Let's trick them,' said Dog.

the_street_band_13.script: So Dog beat the drums. Sheep went 'bleat.' Cat tapped his feet. Bird made a 'tweet.' 'Let's leave!' said the men.

the_street_band_14.script: So Dog, Sheep, Cat, and Bird went in. Now they can sleep, eat, and keep their beat in their band.

the_street_band_2.script: 'I will go to town to beat the drums,' Dog said. 'There I will be needed.' So he ran down the street.

the_street_band_3.script: Who did he meet? Dog met a sheep. 'I am too weak to work. My man does not need me,' she said.

the_street_band_4.script: 'Come to town,' said Dog. 'I will beat and you can bleat. There we will be needed.' So they ran down the street.

the_street_band_5.script: Who did they meet? Dog and Sheep met a cat. 'I am too weak to work. My woman does not need me,' he said.

the_street_band_6.script: 'Come to town,' said Sheep. 'I will bleat and you can tap your feet. There we will be needed.' So they ran down the street.

the_street_band_7.script: Who did they meet? Dog, Sheep, and Cat met a bird. 'I am too weak to work. My man does not need me,' she said.

the_street_band_8.script: 'Come to town,' said Cat. 'I will tap my feet and you can tweet. There we will be needed.' So they ran down the street.

the_street_band_9.script: 'I need meat,' Dog said. 'The heat!' Sheep said.
